title: DEBRIEFING ABOUT THE DECEPTION USED IN THE STUDY

body.caption: Thank you for participating!
words: Earlier, we informed you that our study was about measuring aspect of cognition. While this is true, we were specifically interested in the effects of stress on cognition. As a result, half of the participants in the study saw unpleasant videos and completed a very stressful math game in order to create a short-term stressful experience.

In order to properly study this, it was required that we deceive you about the actual nature of the study. We could not warn you that you would experience stress because knowing this in advance would have minimized the experience of the stress.
The specific deception elements in this study included:
&nbsp 1) Not telling you in the consent form that this study was about the effects of stress on cognition.
&nbsp 2) If you were part of the stress group:
a. Telling you you were doing badly on the math game no matter your actual performance.
b. Telling you you had to maintain a certain performance level which was not true. In fact, we are not at all interested in performance on this game. This was only to cause stress.
c. Watching unpleasant videos without warning.
Given the ubiquitous nature of stress, it is critical that we study it in order to understand the range of consequences it can hold for brain health.

We followed standard research procedures commonly used to cause stress in the research setting. The stress was meant to be relatively mild and very short-term. If you still feel lingering effects of this stress, or have any questions about the study or your rights as a participant, please contact us: Madeleine Sharp, Department of Neurology and Neurosurgery, Montr√©al Neurological Institute, McGill University madeleine.sharp@mcgill.ca or sharplab.neuro@mcgill.ca
